deliberation: Considered the time and place markers as literal. Focused on the clause 'the heavens were opened' (נִפְתְּחוּ הַשָּׁמַיִם), which is a conventional theophanic idiom picturing the sky as a door or barrier being opened, thus using metaphor and mild personification. 'Visions of God' is a genitive of source and need not be figurative in form.

instances.english_text: the heavens opened
target: the onset of Ezekiel’s visionary experience
vehicle: a door/portal being opened in the sky
ground: sudden removal of a barrier giving access and visibility
posture: Ezekiel’s report of how revelation begins
instances.explanation: The sky is portrayed as if it were a door that can be opened, a conventional idiom for God granting revelatory access.

deliberation: Purely chronological data specifying the date relative to Jehoiachin’s exile. No comparisons, anthropomorphisms, or idiomatic expressions beyond normal historical notation.

Examined two stereotyped prophetic formulas: 'the word of YHWH came to...' and 'the hand of YHWH was upon him.' Both are stock figurative idioms: the first portrays the divine message as an approaching entity, the second uses 'hand' as metonymy for divine power and control, further metaphorically 'coming upon' the prophet.

instances.english_text: the word of the LORD came to Ezekiel
target: God’s act of revealing a message to Ezekiel
vehicle: a 'word' moving toward and arriving at someone
ground: the experience of a message being received from outside oneself
posture: Ezekiel’s self-description of being addressed by God
instances.explanation: The divine message is personified and metaphorically depicted as something that can 'come' to the prophet, a standard prophetic idiom.

instances.english_text: and the hand of the LORD came upon him there
target: Ezekiel’s experience of being overpowered/controlled by God
divine power exerted on the prophet
vehicle: a hand resting upon or taking hold of someone
ground: being seized, directed, or empowered by another’s force
posture: Ezekiel’s description of being seized by God’s power
instances.explanation: 'Hand' stands metonymically for God’s power, and that power is metaphorically said to come upon Ezekiel as a hand taking hold of him.

deliberation: The storm-wind, cloud, and fire are presented as elements of the seen vision, not overt figures in the wording. The explicit comparison is in the phrase 'as the appearance of ḥashmal,' which functions as a visual simile for the inner radiance.

instances.english_text: and in the center of it, in the center of the fire, a gleam as of amber (electrum)
target: the bright core seen within the storm-fire
posture: Ezekiel’s attempt to describe what he sees
instances.explanation: Ezekiel uses a simile to liken the inner radiance of the theophany to the gleam of a bright metal called ḥashmal.

deliberation: The verse twice uses דְּמוּת ('likeness') terminology, indicating resemblance rather than identity. The creatures are not literally humans but have 'the likeness of a human,' which functions as a conceptual metaphor of form similarity, even if couched in visionary description.

instances.hebrew_text: דְּמוּת אַרְבַּע חַיּוֹת ... דְּמוּת אָדָם לָהֵנָּה
instances.english_text: the figures (likenesses) of four creatures... They had the figures (likeness) of human beings
target: the form of the four living creatures
vehicle: the form of a human being
posture: Ezekiel’s way of approximating unfamiliar beings
instances.explanation: Ezekiel characterizes the non-human creatures by metaphorically mapping them onto the familiar form of a human, using 'likeness' language.

deliberation: Straightforward anatomical description ('four faces,' 'four wings') of visionary beings; no comparative particles or conventional idioms. Symbolism may be present, but the language itself is not figurative.
Noted two explicit כְּ ('like/as') comparisons: the feet 'like a calf’s hoof' and the sparkle 'like burnished bronze.' Both are visual similes applied to the creatures' lower limbs.

instances.english_text: and the feet of each were like a single calf’s hoof
target: the shape of the creatures’ feet
anatomical feature of the living creatures
posture: Ezekiel’s visual comparison of unfamiliar anatomy
instances.explanation: The creatures’ feet are compared to a calf’s hoof to convey their unusual, hoof-like form.

instances.english_text: and they sparkled like the luster of burnished bronze
target: the visual quality of the creatures’ feet/legs
instances.explanation: The shine of the creatures’ legs is likened to polished bronze to convey their metallic brilliance.

deliberation: Describes placement of hands, faces, and wings without comparative markers or conventional figurative idioms. Though the beings themselves are symbolic, this line’s language is straightforward.
The joining of wings and straight movement are mechanical descriptions of the vision’s dynamics. No explicit metaphor, simile, or idiom in the wording itself.

Faces of man, lion, ox, and eagle are presented as literal features of the seen composite beings. These carry symbolic value, but linguistically they function as direct description, not as comparisons ('like a lion') or other figures.
Literal description of wings’ arrangement and coverage of the body. No figurative turns of phrase are present.

The movement 'wherever the spirit would go' could be theologically rich, but in the wording it simply states that their motion followed the ruach. No clear metaphor or simile phrase; ruach can literally denote spirit here rather than personified wind.

This verse explicitly likens the appearance associated with the creatures to 'burning coals of fire' and to 'torches.' Both are separate similes using כְּ ('like/as'), even if describing the same luminous phenomenon.

instances.english_text: their appearance was like burning coals of fire
target: the luminous appearance among the creatures
instances.explanation: The radiant phenomenon among the creatures is compared to glowing coals to express its fiery, ember-like quality.

instances.english_text: like the appearance of torches
target: the moving fiery look between the creatures
ground: moving points of flame and light
posture: Ezekiel’s elaboration of the same phenomenon
instances.explanation: He further compares the fire among the creatures to torches, emphasizing the mobile, flickering character of the light.

deliberation: The motion 'running and returning' is literal-of-vision. The explicit simile is 'like the appearance of the lightning' (כְּמַרְאֵה הַבָּזָק), describing the creatures’ speed.

instances.english_text: like the appearance of a flash of lightning
target: the speed and suddenness of the creatures’ motion
ground: extreme swiftness and sudden, bright movement
instances.explanation: Their rapid back-and-forth motion is likened to a lightning flash to convey speed and suddenness.

deliberation: A straightforward note that a wheel was on the earth beside each creature. No explicit figurative language in the verse’s wording.

Identified two explicit comparative expressions: wheels 'like beryl' (כְּעֵין תַּרְשִׁישׁ) and the structure 'as when a wheel is within a wheel' (כַּאֲשֶׁר יִהְיֶה הָאוֹפַן בְּתוֹךְ הָאוֹפָן). Both are similes clarifying color and configuration.

instances.english_text: the appearance of the wheels... gleamed like beryl
posture: Ezekiel’s attempt to convey chromatic effect
instances.explanation: The wheels’ gleam is likened to beryl to indicate their gemstone-like radiance.

instances.hebrew_text: וּמַרְאֵיהֶם וּמַעֲשֵׂיהֶם כַּאֲשֶׁר יִהְיֶה הָאוֹפַן בְּתוֹךְ הָאוֹפָן
instances.english_text: their appearance and structure was as of a wheel within a wheel
target: the structural configuration of each wheel unit
vehicle: the arrangement of one wheel inside another wheel
ground: interpenetrating circular forms allowing multi-directional movement
instances.explanation: He likens what he saw to a known configuration of a wheel set inside another wheel, to explain how they could move in any direction.

deliberation: Describes directional movement without veering. No comparative particles or metaphorical idioms in this verse.

The rims being 'full of eyes' might be symbolically charged, but within the vision report they are presented as literal features Ezekiel saw, not as a metaphor ('as if with eyes'). No explicit figurative formulation.
Mechanical coupling of movement between creatures and wheels is described literally. No similes, metaphors, or idioms beyond straightforward narrative.

The ruach (spirit) in the wheels is a theological concept, but the wording 'wherever the spirit would go, they went' is a direct statement of agency within the vision, not cast as a comparison or image.
This verse reiterates the coordinated motion of creatures and wheels; still no explicit figurative expressions in the wording.
Noted the explicit comparison of the expanse above the heads to 'the fearsome/awesome ice/crystal' using כְּעֵין. This is a simile describing visual appearance.

instances.english_text: an expanse, with an awe-inspiring gleam as of crystal (ice)
target: the appearance of the expanse above the creatures
posture: Ezekiel’s description of the heavenly expanse
instances.explanation: The dome above the creatures is likened to fearsome crystal or ice to evoke its awe-inspiring, brilliant, and solid appearance.

deliberation: Describes how the wings are stretched out and covering the bodies beneath the expanse. No comparative constructions or stock figurative idioms are used.

This verse is rich in sound imagery with three separate כְּקוֹל ('like the sound of') similes: like many waters, like the voice of Shaddai, like the din of an army camp. All three are distinct vehicles for the auditory impression of the wings.

instances.english_text: the sound of their wings was like the sound of mighty waters
target: the volume and character of the wing-sound
auditory effect of the creatures’ movement
posture: Ezekiel’s first attempt to convey the sound
instances.explanation: He likens the wings’ sound to the roar of abundant waters to express its powerful, rushing quality.

instances.english_text: like the sound of Shaddai
vehicle: the sound associated with Shaddai (the Almighty)
posture: Ezekiel’s theological framing of the sound
instances.explanation: He compares the sound to what one would associate with the powerful voice of Shaddai, emphasizing its divine, awe-filled character.

instances.english_text: a tumult like the din of an army (camp)
target: the complexity and tumult of the wing-sound
auditory impression of movement and noise
vehicle: the sound of an army camp
posture: Ezekiel’s additional comparison for the same sound
instances.explanation: By comparing the noise to an army camp’s din, he conveys multiplicity, power, and organized tumult in the sound.

deliberation: A voice is heard from above the expanse; wings droop when they stand still. This is narratively straightforward with no explicit comparisons or idiomatic metaphors in the wording.

The verse uses דְּמוּת ('likeness') repeatedly and includes an explicit visual simile: the throne-like form is 'in appearance like sapphire' (כְּמַרְאֵה אֶבֶן־סַפִּיר). I treat that comparison as the primary figurative expression.

instances.english_text: the semblance of a throne, in appearance like sapphire
target: the color and brilliance of the throne-like form
visual quality of the heavenly throne
ground: intense, gem-like blue brilliance and clarity
posture: Ezekiel’s attempt to portray the divine throne
instances.explanation: He likens the appearance of the throne to sapphire to convey its jewel-like, radiant, and royal character.

deliberation: The upper and lower parts of the human-like figure are each described with luminous comparisons: 'a gleam as of ḥashmal, like the appearance of fire' above, and 'like the appearance of fire' below. These form two related but distinct similes for different segments of the figure.

instances.hebrew_text: כְּעֵין חַשְׁמַל כְּמַרְאֵה־אֵשׁ בֵּית־לָהּ סָבִיב מִמַּרְאֵה מָתְנָיו וּלְמָעְלָה
instances.english_text: a gleam as of amber, like the appearance of fire encased all around, from what appeared as his loins up
target: the upper part of the radiant human-like figure
visible manifestation of divine glory above the loins
ground: intense, enclosed, fiery brilliance with metallic hue
posture: Ezekiel’s description of the upper body of the figure
instances.explanation: He likens the upper torso to amber and encased fire to stress its concentrated, fiery radiance.

instances.english_text: and from what appeared as his loins down, I saw what looked like fire
target: the lower part of the figure from loins downward
posture: Ezekiel’s description of the lower body
instances.explanation: The lower torso is simply likened to fire, underscoring the total fiery nature of the figure.

deliberation: The main explicit figure is the simile comparing the surrounding radiance to a rainbow in the clouds on a rainy day. 'Appearance of the likeness of the glory of YHWH' is theological but structurally descriptive. Falling on his face is both literal in context and an idiom for prostration, but here it coincides with actual action, so I prioritize the clear simile.

instances.hebrew_text: כְּמַרְאֵה הַקֶּשֶׁת אֲשֶׁר יִהְיֶה בֶעָנָן בְּיוֹם הַגֶּשֶׁם כֵּן מַרְאֵה הַנֹּגַהּ סָבִיב
instances.english_text: Like the appearance of the bow that is in the cloud on a day of rain, such was the appearance of the surrounding radiance
target: the radiance encircling the divine figure
vehicle: a rainbow in the cloud on a rainy day
ground: circular surrounding configuration and multicolored brightness
posture: Ezekiel’s final characterization of the glory’s radiance
instances.explanation: He compares the encircling radiance of the divine glory to a rainbow, highlighting its circular, multicolored brilliance and evoking covenantal associations.
